private_information: I can only pick up and move blocks whose labels are vowels (A, E, I, O, U).
I may interact with only the top block of any stack and only one block at a time.
I can place a moved block either on the table or on top of any other block that is presently top of its stack.
vowel_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks so that the final stack order from top to bottom is A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, and K on the table.

private_information: I can only pick up and move blocks whose labels are consonants (all letters except A, E, I, O, U).
I may interact with only the top block of any stack and only one block at a time.
I can place a moved block either on the table or on top of any other block that is presently top of its stack.
consonant_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks so that the final stack order from top to bottom is A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, and K on the table.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate agent observations and capabilities and produce a single PDDL domain and PDDL problem targeting the FastDownwards solver that will achieve the specified final stack configuration while keeping vowel and consonant actions distinct.

public_information: There are blocks labeled J, G, E, D, I, B, F, H, K, A, C.

Initial stacking: J is on the table, G is on top of J, E is on the table, D is on top of G, I is on top of E, B is on top of I, F is on top of D, H is on top of F, K is on top of B, A is on top of H, C is on top of A.
Only top blocks of each stack are accessible for moves.
Each move manipulates exactly one top block at a time and moves it either onto the table or onto another top block.
Vowel blocks are A, E, I, O, U. Vowel blocks may be moved only by the vowel agent.
Consonant blocks may be moved only by the consonant agent.
The global goal is to produce a single stacked sequence where A is on B, B is on C, C is on D, D is on E, E is on F, F is on G, G is on H, H is on I, I is on J, J is on K, and K is on the table.

analysis.system_prompt: You are an expert in block-manipulation constraints and agent capability summaries. Provide a clear capability and observation report constrained to your private knowledge. Do not output PDDL here. Describe which blocks you can move, which top blocks are currently accessible to you, any local ordering constraints you observe, and any assumptions you require to perform moves.
analysis.prompt: Your name is vowel_agent. You are operating in an environment with the following public information: {environment->public_information} You have the following private information: {agents->vowel_agent->private_information} This is the common goal to achieve: {agents->vowel_agent->goal} Provide a step-by-step capability and observation report: list the vowel blocks present, identify which of those are initially top blocks you can legally move, state the legal move types you can perform, enumerate any local constraints or dependencies you see, and state any missing information you need. Do not produce PDDL. Output a concise, machine-readable analysis summary that the orchestrator can consume.

analysis.system_prompt: You are an expert in block-manipulation constraints and agent capability summaries. Provide a clear capability and observation report constrained to your private knowledge. Do not output PDDL here. Describe which blocks you can move, which top blocks are currently accessible to you, any local ordering constraints you observe, and any assumptions you require to perform moves.
analysis.prompt: Your name is consonant_agent. You are operating in an environment with the following public information: {environment->public_information} You have the following private information: {agents->consonant_agent->private_information} This is the common goal to achieve: {agents->consonant_agent->goal} Provide a step-by-step capability and observation report: list the consonant blocks present, identify which of those are initially top blocks you can legally move, state the legal move types you can perform, enumerate any local constraints or dependencies you see, and state any missing information you need. Do not produce PDDL. Output a concise, machine-readable analysis summary that the orchestrator can consume.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent PDDL modeling for the FastDownwards planner. Using the analyses provided by the agents, produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that encode the block-moving problem and respect agent capability constraints. The PDDL domain must make agent actions explicit and distinct: prefix action names or include agent-specific predicates so that moves performed by the vowel agent and the consonant agent are distinguishable. The domain and problem must be compatible with FastDownwards and include types, predicates, objects, initial state, and goal. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. If information is missing from the agents' reports, state the minimal assumptions you make and include them in comments inside the PDDL problem file.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Integrate the following sources: public environment information {environment->public_information}, the vowel agent analysis {analysis_vowel}, and the consonant agent analysis {analysis_consonant}. Your task is to produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem targeting the FastDownwards solver that achieves the global goal: A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, and K on the table. Ensure agent actions remain distinct in the domain (for example, move-vowel and move-consonant actions or actions annotated with agent identifiers). Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> and the problem between <problem></problem>. If you assume any tie-breaking or naming conventions, document them inside the PDDL problem comments.
